results.content:
The two main things I have noticed are, the content focuses on making sure you have everything you need to achieve what want to do.
Although working with React is a skill that gets developed over time, I think this course has a great foundation for it.

As for the presentation: the video quality, visibility of code set this one apart. And Mark's energy and approach is helpful. The way he has focused on creating a community of learners is refreshing.

Looking forward to spending more time to complete this course.

results.content:
This course helped me get in ReactJs . I am an experienced Java 2E developer but Node.js and Javascript stuff I didn't know before that.
French is my mother tongue.
I understand english.
Mark is so clear (and funny), you can go on in the course and learn stuff.
His mindset is clearly. Learn something simple, useful, actionnable you will use in your next project.
This course is not for people who want to implement directly in a Rails app . But if you plan to create a Node .js web app you can go for this course no problem. You will learn the stuff fast (it took me 5 day to complete the course). This course will challenge you to create stuff with the knowledge along the way (you really learn by doing). And something he talk a lot or repeat stuff but Hey ! that's the way , that's how stuff stay in your mind. Teaching looks easy that's not the case and I think Mark Price do it well :). 
So you you want useful/simple/actionnable ReactJs knowledge? You can take this course.
results.content_html:

This course is not for people who want to implement directly in a Rails app . But if you plan to create a Node .js web app you can go for this course no problem. You will learn the stuff fast (it took me 5 day to complete the course). This course will challenge you to create stuff with the knowledge along the way (you really learn by doing). And something he talk a lot or repeat stuff but Hey ! that's the way , that's how stuff stay in your mind. Teaching looks easy that's not the case and I think Mark Price do it well :).
So you you want useful/simple/actionnable ReactJs knowledge? You can take this course.

results.content: Mark always does a great job explaining concepts to students without requiring that they have a huge background in programming. His longer courses are more in-depth and help you feel a little more confident that you have a wider knowledge of the subject, but this one will definitely get you up and running in react whether you're new to it or just need a refresher. Big fan of any course Mark teaches. (Devslopes in general is decent, but I find the Devslopes courses taught by Mark are particularly good and worth the money)

His longer courses are more in-depth and help you feel a little more confident that you have a wider knowledge of the subject, but this one will definitely get you up and running in react whether you're new to it or just need a refresher. results.content: I love that Mark doesn't script everything out and have code snippets ready to go - he does everything live with you. If there are issues that need to be debugged, he goes through the debugging process - you get to see how these problems are solved. After completing this course, I can't wait to start building my own React projects to solidify the concepts that I learned in this course, as well as gain new skills moving forward. Looking to learn React? Take this course!

results.content:
As a complete newbie to React, this course was excellent. Mark explained the core concepts very clearly. The projects he has us do are fun & challenging. What I really enjoyed about the course is how the projects required a lot of discovery - he didn't spoon-feed the ideas. He instead gave very simple and clear examples and challenged you to build upon them yourself.

One thing that would've been helpful for me, personally, is a little bit more explanation of how React could be used/integrated with databases & modern server-side frameworks. He touches on it, but now at the end of this course, I find myself wondering what the best learning route would be following this for back-end - Node.js? MongoDB? Should I delve into Redux? A bit more clarity there would've helped.

That being said,  I've learned a lot from this, and I'm excited to continue moving forward with my studies. I highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to learn React. Thank you Mark!
results.content_html:
As a complete newbie to React, this course was excellent. Mark explained the core concepts very clearly. The projects he has us do are fun & challenging. What I really enjoyed about the course is how the projects required a lot of discovery - he didn't spoon-feed the ideas. He instead gave very simple and clear examples and challenged you to build upon them yourself.

One thing that would've been helpful for me, personally, is a little bit more explanation of how React could be used/integrated with databases & modern server-side frameworks. He touches on it, but now at the end of this course, I find myself wondering what the best learning route would be following this for back-end - Node.js? MongoDB? Should I delve into Redux? A bit more clarity there would've helped.

That being said, I've learned a lot from this, and I'm excited to continue moving forward with my studies. I highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to learn React. Thank you Mark!

results.content: This is a fantastic course for people wanting to learn modern web application development who know basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Mark walks through real world examples that will help people in real jobs and gives a great practical overview of React, Flux/Reflux, Node, and NPM. Anyone scared/lost/confused with Node and Browserify and builds and modern weird JavaScript geekiness should take this course for a fantastic grounding and a huge leg up.
results.content_html: This is a fantastic course for people wanting to learn modern web application development who know basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Mark walks through real world examples that will help people in real jobs and gives a great practical overview of React, Flux/Reflux, Node, and NPM. Anyone scared/lost/confused with Node and Browserify and builds and modern weird JavaScript geekiness should take this course for a fantastic grounding and a huge leg up.

results.content:
This course started off great as Mark explained in depth about React. The course started to do downhill when it started into the react-router section. The version of react-router used in this course is version 3 while the latest version is version 4. React-router dramatically changed its API from v3 to v4 so all of this section is completely outdated. 
The course is outdated and doesn't seem like it will be updated anytime soon. There's also no instructor feedback. Every video we are told to join a chat group for any questions or discussions. When I tried this, I messaged Mark directly and he completely ignored my question.

All in all I wouldn't recommend this course and it is definitely not worth the money. There are far better and more up to date React courses on here
results.content_html:
This course started off great as Mark explained in depth about React. The course started to do downhill when it started into the react-router section. The version of react-router used in this course is version 3 while the latest version is version 4. React-router dramatically changed its API from v3 to v4 so all of this section is completely outdated.
The course is outdated and doesn't seem like it will be updated anytime soon. There's also no instructor feedback. Every video we are told to join a chat group for any questions or discussions. When I tried this, I messaged Mark directly and he completely ignored my question.

All in all I wouldn't recommend this course and it is definitely not worth the money. There are far better and more up to date React courses on here

results.content:
Pros:
-His way of explaining concepts is down to earth, with good energy. 

-He does a good review before jumping into React

Note: Edited earlier review to reflect the videos I'm currently viewing in the course progression (React Skeleton).  

He: 
 -Started being more consistently articulate
 -Began to more accurately describe the evironment on the screen
 -Turned off the clothes dryer
- Really hit his stride...   Bravo

(Still chafing that he called commands used in the terminal Mac commands.  Google Ken Thompson)

results.content:
The way he teaches by breaking things down and draws them out so you understand the bigger picture was very helpful for me. 

If you are not very clear on the basics of react this is a excellent course to take.

Production quality is very good (heard you dropped the black background, I was liking it)

Few things to note
Es6 is not used in the course (I would love to see a lecture of refactoring one one of the apps)
Mixins are used
When using a server it is in a separate folder (had never seen this before, but not a bad thing)
Currently nothing about Relay in the course (I originally took this because it came up when I searched Relay, but I do not regret taking it!)
results.content_html:

results.content: This lecture has really taught me a lot about web development and how to create my own websites
results.content_html: This lecture has really taught me a lot about web development and how to create my own websites

results.content:
This course teaches the basics of react in a very organized way, it help to understand the principles behind react and challenged me through exercise it to understand it deeply.

The instructor was very clear, sometimes even repetitive but in a good way because it explained what he was doing, instead of assuming that the students already understands what he was doing.

All the course material is up to date with the latest versions which is very important in the world of web development.

Finally I just want to say thanks to Mark for making this course which I enjoyed and learned a lot from it.

results.content: I am about 3/4 of the way through and I actually like his style of not having everything scripted out and already set. It's nice actually being able to see him write the code as he goes and run into problems and errors. Being able to see how other people figure out what the problem is also helps. His knowledge of React seems to be pretty good and I like that he goes into detail a lot of the time to explain why he is doing certain things.

results.content: This class was more complete than I expected. It doesn't just teach you how React works, but everything you need to know to do a React project. I especially loved learning how to create a React skeleton (I use it all the time now) and set things up with Flux and other NPM packages. I feel closer to working like a professional programmer. The pacing is good and the explanations are clear.
results.content_html: This class was more complete than I expected. It doesn't just teach you how React works, but everything you need to know to do a React project. I especially loved learning how to create a React skeleton (I use it all the time now) and set things up with Flux and other NPM packages. I feel closer to working like a professional programmer. The pacing is good and the explanations are clear.
